did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The papers consist of memoirs, writings, correspondence, identification documents, and certificates, relating to conditions in Russia prior to, during and after the Russian Revolution, and to Russian émigré life in Harbin, China, France, and the United States. Includes material relating to the Glebov family, as well as the papers of Mikhail Vladimirovich Golitsyn, Aleksandr Vladimirovich Golitsyn and Liubov' Vladimirovna Golitsyna.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1990.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born in Moscow, Russia, to an aristocratic family
Received medical degree from Moscow University
Emigrated with his wife and children to Harbin, China where he worked as a doctor for the Russian Society of the Red Cross
Arrived in Seattle from Harbin, China, and applied for U.S. citizenship
Received U.S. medical license and practiced medicine in Seattle and Los Angeles
Born in Moscow, Russia, to an aristocratic family
Worked for Gosplan, the Soviet state planning committee, until dismissed. Requested reinstatement and was denied
Moved with his family to Dmitrov, Soviet Union
Wrote his memoirs of the pre-revolutionary period, Moi vospominaniia, 1873-1917, published in 2007 by Russkiĭ mir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of memoirs, writings, correspondence, identification documents, and certificates, relating to conditions in Russia prior to, during and after the Russian Revolution, and to Russian émigré life in Harbin, China, France, and the United States. Includes material relating to the Glebov family, as well as the papers of Mikhail Vladimirovich Golitsyn, Aleksandr Vladimirovich Golitsyn and Liubov' Vladimirovna Golitsyna.

The bulk of the collection is comprised of correspondence among members of the Glebov and Golitsyn families. Writing to their daughter from exile in France, Sofiia and Vladimir Glebov's letters document Russian émigré life in western Europe, while the letters of Mikhail Vladimirovich Golitsyn to his brother Aleksandr describe conditions in Russia after the Bolshevik revolution. Of particular interest in the Correspondence series are letters from Nestor, the Archbishop of Kamchatka and Seoul, on Russian refugees in Harbin, China, and the Russian Orthodox Church in exile.

The Aleksandr Golitsyn Career Files relate to the Russian Society of the Red Cross's efforts to resettle the Russian refugees of Harbin in Canada. Memoranda and correspondence with Canadian officials and Serge Ughet, the financial attaché of the Russian embassy, document measures to secure visas and jobs for Russian immigrants on the Canadian Pacific railway. A report to the League of Nations describes the bleak conditions at orphanages for Russian refugee children in China.

Several memoirs by members of the Glebov and Golitsyn families are included in the Writings series. In "Intimate Days with Tolstoy," Sofiia Glebova recalls conversations with the writer Leo Tolstoy at Iasnaia Poliana after her daughter's marriage to Tolstoy's son. Memoirs by Mikhail Golitsyn and Vladimir Trubetskoĭ describe aristocratic life in Russia at the beginning of the 20th century. "Sudebnoe delo sem'i Vladimira Sergeevicha Trubetskogo" consists of assembled correspondence and reports on the fate of five members of the Trubetskoi family executed or sentenced to the gulag in 1937.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.subject: Russians--China.
Russians--United States.

scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence among members of the Glebov and Golitsyn families, primarily to Liubov' Golitsyna from her parents and to Aleksandr Golitsyn from his brother Mikhail. Divided into two subseries: general correspondence and Russian Orthodox Church correspondence. Arranged by correspondent and thereunder chronologically

Consists mainly of letters from Sofiia Nikolaevna Glebova (née Trubetskaia) and Vladimir Petrovich Glebov to their daughter Liubov'. Also includes correspondence from Glebov siblings and unidentified relatives
Consists mainly of letters from Mikhail Vladimirovich Golitsyn to his brother Aleksandr. Also includes correspondence from Aleksandr's parents, Vladimir Mikhaĭlovich Golitsyn and Sofiia Golitsyna

did.unittitle: Ughet, Serge, financial attaché of the Russian Embassy in the U.S.,
Baranoff, Makary, Rector of the Russian Orthodox Church of Juneau, Alaska,
Nestor, Archbishop of Kamchatka and Seoul (Nikolai Aleksandrovich Anisimov), Harbin,

scopecontent.p: Includes postcard with photograph of Nestor

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous correspondence related to the Russian Orthodox Church,

scopecontent.p: Contains certificates, receipts, school reports, ledgers, and visa applications by Liubov' and Aleksandr Golitsyn. Arranged chronologically

did.unittitle: Rental agreement and property insurance records,
Safe conduct passes and certificates of employment for Liubov' and Aleksandr Golitsyn,
Report cards for Ol'ga, Natalia, and Aleksandr Golitsyn,
Donation to a tuberculosis charity signed by Liubov' Golitsyna,
Affidavit of intent to become a United States citizen by Aleksandr Golitsyn,
United States visas for Liubov' and Aleksandr Golitsyn and children,

scopecontent.p: Includes photographs

Includes memoranda, correspondence, surveys, receipts, and notes related to Aleksandr Golitsyn's medical career and his work with refugees in Harbin for the Russian Society of the Red Cross. Arranged in three groups: Russia and United States career files, Russian Society of the Red Cross in China files, and Miscellany; and thereunder chronologically

"To Canadian Immigration Authorities in Regard to Possible Absorption by Canada of Part of Russian Refugees from Manchuria,"

scopecontent.p: On settling Russian refugees in Canada

scopecontent.p: Relates to employing Russian refugees on railroad construction projects

Harbin Club calling card and invitation,

scopecontent.p: Consists of memoirs, published and unpublished writings, and notes relating to pre-Revolutionary Russia, Leo Tolstoy, the Russian Orthodox Church and the Stalin era. Arranged in two groups: By author and Author unknown, and thereunder alphabetically

did.unittitle: Gleboff, Sophie, "Intimate Days with Tolstoy," translated by Lewis Stanton Palen, typescript with corrections, Paris,

scopecontent.p: Gleboff describes her visits with the writer Leo Tolstoy after her daughter Aleksandra's marriage to Tolstoy's son Mikhail

did.unittitle: Golitsyn, Aleksandr Mikhaĭlovich, Pamiatnyia zapiski Kniazia Aleksandra Mikhaĭlovicha Golitsyna, typescript,
Golitsyn, Mikhail Vladimirovich, Moi vospominaniia, 1873-1917, photocopy of typescript,
Nestor, Archbishop of Kamchatka and Seoul (Nikolai Aleksandrovich Anisimov), religious writings,

scopecontent.p: Consists of tracts by Nestor on religious holidays and profiles of Patriarkh Tikhon and Arkhiepiskop Nikolai Iaponskiĭ
Tolstaia's memoirs of her childhood at the Glebov family estate, Barykovka
Relates to the Russian Imperial Kirasir Household Troops Regiment of Her Majesty Mariia Feodorovna during the period 1911-1913
One typescript page with corrections in English

Relates to the rehabilitation of several members of the Trubetskoĭ family, including Vladimir Sergeevich (1891-1937) and Varvara Vladimirovna (1917-1937), both executed by the NKVD in Andizhan. Two other Trubetskoĭ family members, Grigoriĭ Vladmirovich and Aleksandra Vladimirovna, were sentenced to the gulag in 1937 for counterrevolutionary activities
